Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Astronomy and Informatics at the MIT Haystack Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
MIT's Haystack Observatory will host a combined summer REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) and RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) site in astronomy, space sciences, geodesy, and informatics. The program will strive to recruit diverse student cohorts including students from underrepresented groups, as well as students from colleges and universities with limited local research infrastructure. The research and professional development programs will help students to understand the nature and ethics of scientific research and the skills and process necessary to become a professional scientist. Instructional Units developed by RET participants will be used in classrooms worldwide.

These activities are linked through an overarching radio science theme. Each summer, seven undergraduate students and two K-12 teachers will spend ten weeks at Haystack engaged in research. Most of these will utilize major on-site facilities and instrumentation. Opportunities also exist for students to get involved with the Event Horizon Telescope, very long baseline interferometry, the Murchison Widefield Array, and in designing instrumentation for these and future facilities. The program is also a gateway to opportunities in various geospace and magnetospheric physics projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MIT Haystack Observatory REU program provides undergraduates with a hands-on, practical research experience over the course of a summer. In our program, students are mentored for ten weeks by experienced scientists on a research project designed to encourage those considering a career in a related scientific field in a congenial educational environment. Undergraduate interns submit a final report and present their project results at the end of the summer.

The Haystack REU program includes an extensive seminar series, in which program participants attend interactive discussions and lectures offered by Haystack staff members. These talks provide in-depth coverage of the wide range of radio science research across the observatory, enabling students to better understand and appreciate the work of their undergraduate colleagues and Haystack scientists in the program across related disciplines. Subjects range from radio astronomy to atmospheric science, geodesy, engineering, programming, and many others.

In addition to the seminars on specific topics in radio science, students attend career-focused talks offering guidance on writing successful proposals, applying to graduate school and potential paths to follow after graduation, and the importance of communicating science to various audiences.

Students in the program may be co-authors on published journal articles based on their research projects, and may continue to work with their mentors after the end of the summer program. Many of the projects significantly advance the state of important research efforts at the observatory, and all students become integral members of the staff research team for the summer.

Feedback from the students is consistently positive throughout the duration of the award, and indicates that the experience at Haystack facilitated their understanding of the nature of research and provided information that helped them make informed career decisions. For many, it confirms their choice to pursue a PhD degree and start a research career; Haystack researchers are often delighted to see their former REU students making great progress as new colleagues in the field.

All students in the program deliver high-quality presentations of their work to an audience of staff from across the observatory in the final week of the program, thereby developing valuable skills of public speaking, professional presentation, and science communication—all invaluable to those who continue in STEM careers.
